statement.p: Evaluate each of the integrals \int_0^1 f(x) \,dx, \int_0^1 g(x) \,dx, and \int_0^1 h(x) \,dx exactly using the First FTC.

hint.p: Find antiderivatives to evaluate the integrals exactly.

md.mrow: \int_0^1 f(x) dx \amp = \frac{5}{3} \amp \int_0^1 g(x) dx \amp = \frac{7}{4} \amp \int_0^1 h(x) dx \amp = \frac{9}{5}

solution.p: The exact values of the three definite integrals are \int_0^1 f(x) dx \amp = \frac{5}{3} \amp \int_0^1 g(x) dx \amp = \frac{7}{4} \amp \int_0^1 h(x) dx \amp = \frac{9}{5}\amp \approx 1.6667 \amp \amp = 1.75 \amp \amp = 1.8

statement.p: For each of the three functions f, g, and h, compare the results of L_1, R_1, M_1, T_1, and S_2 to the true value of the corresponding definite integral. What patterns do you observe?

hint.p: Think about trends in over- and under-estimates.

solution.p: We observe that each of the left endpoint rule results are overestimates, each of the right endpoint rules are underestimates, each of the midpoint rules are overestimates, and each of the trapezoid rules are underestimates. These results hold because each of the three functions are both decreasing and concave down. For Simpson's rule, we see that the result is exact for both f and g, while Simpson's rule is a slight underestimate of \int_0^1 h(x) dx.
